castList.head: DRAMATIS PERSONÆ.
Chestnut-Street.
castList.castItem: Mary ( adopted daughter of Copp ) Mrs. Knight.

set.p: Time of representation — One hour and fifty minutes.

div.head: Scene I
div.stage: — The Royal Palace.
Enter Rochester and Lady Clara , R. H.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Yes, my lord, her majesty will have it, that you are the chief cause of the king's irregularities.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Oh, I'll warrant it; and of his not loving her too — is it not so?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: I did not say that; but, in truth, my lord, your continual jests on the married state —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Heaven bless it!

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Your continual ridicule of married men —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Heaven help them!

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Your licentious example, and still more licentious poetry —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: What's coming next?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: All these, I say, make you the most dangerous of men.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Dangerous! My dear Lady Clara, you make me vain.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: It is well known that you are the king's prime companion in all his excesses.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
What, is my loyalty to be made my reproach? Must I not stand by my monarch in all his moods? — Would you have me weep when my sovereign laughs? Would you have me whine when my sovereign calls for a jolly song? No, no, my lady, that might have done in the days of the Roundheads; but times are
altered. We have a merry monarch to reign over us — A merry monarch, makes a merry court — so God save the jovial king, and send him boon companions!

div.stage: (X L.)

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: I see it is in vain to reason with you.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Then give over the attempt. Let us talk of something of a nearer and a dearer interest — of your merits and my most ardent flame.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Ah me! I fear, like many other of your flames, it will but end in smoke. You talk of being desperately in love, what proof have you ever given?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: What proof? Am I not ready to give the greatest proof that man can offer — to lay down this sweet bachelor life, and commit matrimony for your sake?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p:
Well, this last, I must say, coming from a Rochester, is a most convincing proof. I have heard you out, listen now to me.
( Rochester bows. )
I will propose a bargain. If, by your ascendancy over the king, you can disgust him with these nocturnal rambles, and bring him back to reason —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: To reason! your ladyship forgets one of my talents.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Which is it?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: That of getting myself banished two or three times a year.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: And if the woman you profess to love should offer to partake your exile? —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: I am a lost man — I surrender. — That last shot reached my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Ah, my lord — if that heart were only worth your head! — Well, is it agreed?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: It is your will — I undertake the sacrifice — but, madam, bear in mind my recompense.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: You may hope for every thing. Adieu, my lord. — I now begin to believe in your passion, since you are willing to make a sacrifice to it, even of your follies.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
A pretty task I have undertaken, truly! I — Rochester — become reformer! I who am
considered by all the pious saints about Court, as the ringleader of all mischief. And, then, the convert I have to work upon? Charles, who glories in all kinds of rambling frolics! — True, he has had none but pleasant adventures as yet. If I should trick him into some ridiculous dilemma? — My whole life has been a tissue of follies, and I am called a man of wit. I am now to attempt a rational act, and I shall be called a madman! — Well, be it so — matrimony will be sure to bring me to my senses.

div.stage: Enter Edward , languidly, R. H.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Ah! here comes my young protegé — How downcast he seems! How now, Edward, what's the matter with you, boy?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Nothing, my lord.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Good heaven, what a sigh to heave up nothing with! Tell me the truth this instant. Hast thou dared to fall in love?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I hope, my lord, there is no harm in indulging an honest attachment.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: An honest attachment! A young half-fledged page about court, who has hardly tried his wings in the sunshine of beauty, to talk of an honest attachment. Why thou silly boy, is this the fruit of all the lessons I have given thee?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Did not your lordship tell me, that one of the first duties of a page was to be zealous in his devotion to the fair?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Yes; but I told thee to skim over the surface of beauty, just dipping your wings, like a swallow, not plumping in like a goose — I told you to hover from flower to flower like a butterfly, not to bury yourself in one like a bee. An honest attachment! What a plebeian phrase! — There's a wife and seven children in the very sound of it.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: My lord, I know your talent for putting things in a whimsical light; but, could you see the object of my passion —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Nay, a truce with all description. But who,
pray, is the object of this honest attachment?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: My lord!

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: One of the maids of honour, I'll be bound, who has privately been petting you with sweetmeats and lending you love-tales.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: No, my lord.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Pray, then, give me some clue. What is the name of your beauty?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Her name, my lord, is Mary.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Mary! a very pretty posy-like name — And what sequestered spot may the gentle Mary embellish with her presence?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: She lives at the Tav — Nay, my lord, promise not to laugh.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Far be it from me to laugh in so serious a matter. Come, the residence of this fair one?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Why then, my lord, she inhabits the tavern of the Grand Admiral, in Wapping.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Usquebaugh and tobacco! the tavern of the Grand Admiral! — Ha, ha, ha! An honest attachment to some pretty bar-maid!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: No, my lord, no bar-maid, I assure you. Her uncle keeps the tavern.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Oh, I ask pardon, then she is heiress apparent to the tap-room, and you no doubt look forward to rise in the state through the dignities of drawer, tapster, and head-waiter, until you succeed to the fair hand of the niece, and the copper nose of the uncle, and rule with spigot in hand over the fair realms of Wapping. You, who I flattered myself would have made the torment and delight of all the pretty women at court, — you to be so completely gulled at the very outset, — the dupe of a green girl, and some old rogue of a publican!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Indeed, indeed, my lord, you do the uncle injustice. He is a perfectly honest, upright man — an old captain of a cruiser.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Worse and worse! Some old buccaneer, tired of playing the part of monster at sea, has turned
shork on shore. And do you dare to appear in such a house with the dress of a royal page?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Oh, I have taken care to avoid that. I have introduced myself into the house as a music-master.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: And your musical name, gentle sir?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Georgini, at your service.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! very soft and Italianish — I'll warrant this heroine bar-maid will turn out some unknown princess, carried off by the old buccaneer landlord, in one of his cruisings.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Your lordship is joking; but really, at times; I think she is not what she seems.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I could have sworn it. But, silence — I hear his majesty dismount. Run to where your duty calls — we'll take another opportunity to discuss the merits of this Wapping princess.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: There's many a true thing said in jest. I am certain her birth is above her condition.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
I must see this paragon of bar-maids — She must be devilish pretty! The case admits of no delay — I'll see her this very evening. Hold! why not fulfil my promise to Lady Clara at the same time? It is decided: — I'll give his majesty my first lesson in morals this very night.
[ Two Pages appear. ]
But, he comes.

div.stage: Enter Charles , through door in c. The King, after advancing a little, turns and dismisses the two attendants. They exeunt through c. door.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Good day, my lord! — What, musing! I never see thee with that air of grave cogitation, but I am sure there is some mischief devising.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: On the contrary, I am vehemently tempted to reform.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Reform! — ha, ha, ha! Why, man, no one will credit thy conversion. But what proof do you give of your reformation?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: The most solemn — I am going to be married.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Is that a proof of your returning reason? — Married! And who is the lady you have an idea of rendering miserable?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: The Lady Clara.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: The Lady Clara! The brilliant, the discreet, the virtuous Lady Clara! She marry Rochester! ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Ah, my liege, heaven has given her a super-abundance of virtues. She will be able to make a very virtuous man of me with the superfluity.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Well, when thou art married, I will undertake to write thy epithalamium.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Then your majesty may at once invoke the muses — All is settled.
( with great gravity )
As soon as the rites are solemnized, I shall quit the court and its mundane pleasures, and retire with my lovely bride to my castle at Rochester, under permission of my creditors, the faithful garrison of that fortress.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: What, is your castle again in pledge?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: No, my liege, not again: It has never to my knowledge been exactly out of keeping. A castle requires a custodian.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Ah, Rochester! Rochester! Thou art an extravagant dog! — I see, I shall be called on to pay those usurers at last.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Your majesty is ever bounteous. I should not have dared to solicit, and certainly shall not presume to decline.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! thou art an arrant juggler, and hast an admirable knack of extracting a gift out of an empty hand. But, to business — Where shall we pass the night?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Does your majesty forget that there is a fête to be given at court this evening?

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Nay, prythee, do not talk to me of those dull court ceremonies — I hate etiquette — I love to descend into private life, to doff the monarch, and mingle in the honest revelry of the common people. — There's something of philosophy in this, too — One often gets a useful lesson in the course of a frolic.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
It shall go hard, but your majesty shall have one to-night.
( aloud )
Ah! how few, except myself, give your majesty credit for your philosophy! And yet, by many, I am considered the partaker of your majesty's excesses.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Partaker! what a calumny! you are the promoter of them. Is not thy name a byword? Do not mothers frighten their daughters with it, as formerly with that of Beelzebub? Is not thy appearance in a neighbourhood, a signal for the worthy burghers to bar their windows, and put their womenkind under lock and key? Art thou not, in melancholy truth, the most notorious scapegrace in the whole kingdom?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Heaven forefend that, in anything I should take precedence of your majesty.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Peace, slanderer! who was it [illeg.] ample of the inconstancy I am charged [illeg.]

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Not I, my liege — I set out in [illeg.] pleasure, and have remained constant [illeg.] tions ever since.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
But, pleasure is the object of [illeg.] evening — you shall give another proof [illeg.] stancy to it —
( wearily )
We will attend [illeg.]

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: I must beg your majesty to excuse me. I have an engagement of a grave and important nature this evening.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Grave and important! — thou liest Rochester, or thine eye speaks false. And whither does this grave engagement take thee?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: To the tavern of the Grand Admiral in Wapping.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: The tavern of the Grand Admiral in Wapping. I thought it was to some such haunt. And the object of this business?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: A young girl, beautiful as an angel and virtuous as a dragon.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Angel! There were [illeg.]tions of angels, — one that fell. To which [illeg.] long?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: There is a mystery about her — perchance, some high-born beauty, stolen from her cradle by some bold buccaneer. I am to go this evening and investigate in person.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: A mysterious beauty! It is a case for royal scrutiny — I will investigate it myself.

div.stage: (X to L.)

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: But, my liege —

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: No buts. Provide disguises, my dear Rochester — We will go together.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: But, should some disagreeable adventure occur — —

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I take the consequences on myself. Hush! here comes your intended — I suppose, we must not say a word of the mysterious beauty.

div.stage: Enter Lady Clara, R.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: I am commanded by the Queen to acquaint his majesty, that she hopes for his presence at her fête this evening.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.stage: ( assumes an air of deep abstraction )
sp.p: Impossible, my lady. Tidings of high importance are this moment received — Rochester will explain — My own mind is too fully occupied.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
His majesty is particularly engaged this evening,
( lowering his voice )
to sup at the Grand Admiral in Wapping. —
( aloud )
It is an affair, — an affair, a — a — —

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.stage: ( waves his hand to Rochester to explain )
sp.p: It is an affair of peculiar interest.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Yes, my lady; an affair in which his majesty takes a tender interest — The fate of a
( lowering his voice )
pretty bar-maid depends upon it.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Every thing must assuredly give way to such laudable objects. But my Lord of Rochester's attendance — —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.stage: ( bowing and glancing archly at Charles )
sp.p: Is, as ever, at her majesty's command.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
No, no: Lord Rochester must assist me — He has a particular talent for affairs of this nature. —
( In a low tone to Rochester )
Provide two seamen's d asses, a purse of gold well filled, and arrange every thing for nine precisely.
( aloud )
Fair lady; I salute you — present my loving apologies to her majesty. Lord Rochester, you will attend me.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
I am with your majesty.
( Impressively to Lady Clara )
This night, the lesson; — to-morrow, my disgrace; — within eight days, our marriage, or there is no truth in woman.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Fulfil your part of the engagement, my lord, and rely upon my faith.

div.stage: Exeunt, Roch. L., Lady C. R.
END OF ACT THE FIRST.

div.head: Scene I
div.stage: — Outside of Copp's Tavern, the, Grand. Admiral.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.p:
( Voices within )
Wine! wine! house! — waiter! — more wine, ho! Huzza, huzza, huzza!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
What a noise those sailors make in the bar-room — nothing but singing, and laughing, and shouting — I should like to take a peep at them — but no — my uncle forbids me to show myself in the public rooms — he scarcely lets me be seen by the guests — he brings me up more like a young lady than the niece of a tavern-keeper —
( walks about restless )
. — Heigho! what a tiresome long day! what shall I do with myself? what can be the matter with me? I wonder what can keep Mr. Georgini away? for three days he has not been here to give me a lesson — no matter,
( pettishly )
— I don't care — I shall forget all my singing, that's certain — he was just teaching me such a pretty song too — all about love — I'll try it —
( attempts to sing )
— no, I can't — it's all out of my head —
well, so much the better! I suppose he is teaching it to some fine lady scholar — let him, I don't care — I don't believe he'll find her so apt a scholar.

div.stage: SONG INTRODUCED.
Mrs. Knight.
Enter Copp from the house.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: What, Mary, my little blossom, what cheer, what cheer? Keep close, my little heart — why do you stir out of port? Here be cruisers abroad.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Who are those people, uncle, that make such a noise?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Two hearty blades — mad roysters — oons how they drink. I was obliged to part company, old cruiser as I am, or they would soon have had me on my beam ends.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Are they sailors, uncle?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: To be sure they are; who else would fling about money as they do, and treat a whole bar-room? The tallest in particular is a very devil. Hollo, Captain Copp, cries he every minute, another bottle to treat my brother tars.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: By their swaggering about so, they must be very rich.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Pho, child, 'tisn't the deepest laden ships that make the most rolling.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: But they spend their money so freely.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: A sure sign that it's running out. The longest cable must come to an end. He that pays out fastest, will soonest be brought up with a round turn.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: To what ship do they belong?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
That's more than I can say. Suppose they're a couple of man-of-war's men just paid off, who think they've a Spanish mine in each pocket —
( shout of laughter from within )
. Ah, the jolly tars! I was just the same at their age.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I should like to have a look at them.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Avast there — what, trust thee in the way of two such rovers? No, no, I recollect too well what it
was to get on shore after a long voyage. The first glimpse of a petticoat — whew! up boarding-pikes and grappling-irons! —
( recollecting himself )
Ahem — no, no, child, mustn't venture in these latitudes.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Ah, my good uncle, you are always so careful of me.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: And why not? What else have I in the whole world to care for, or to care for me? Thou art all that's left to me out of the whole family fleet — a poor slight little pinnace. I've seen the rest, one after another, go down; it shall go hard but I'll convoy thee safe into port.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I fear I give you a great deal of trouble, my dear uncle.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Thou'rt the very best lass in the whole kingdom, and I love thee as I loved thy father, my poor brother Philip; that's because you're his very image. To be sure, you haven't his jolly nose, and your little mouth is but a fool to his. But then, there are his eyes, and his smile, and the good humoured cut of his face —
( sighing )
poor Philip! What, I'm going again, like the other night —
( wiping his eyes. )
Psha! let's change the subject, because d'ye see, sensibility and all that gammon, does me no good — none — so let's talk of something else. What makes thee so silent of late, my girl? I've not heard a song from thee these three days!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: It's three days since I've seen my music-master.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Well, and can't you sing without him?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Without him I can't sing well.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: And what's become of him?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I can't tell, its very tiresome. If he did not mean to come again, he might have said so.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oddsfish, neglect thee — neglect his duty! — I'll break him on the spot. Thou shalt have another master. my girl.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
Oh no, on no account; I dare say he is not well, some accident has happened. Besides,
there is no other teacher in town equal to him, he sings with such feeling.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ah! girl, if I had my old messmate, Jack Ratlin, here, he'd teach thee to sing. He had a voice — faith it would make all the bottles dance, and glasses jingle on the table! Talk of feeling! Why, when Jack would sit of an evening on the capstan when on watch, and sing about sweethearts and wives, and jolly tars, and true lover's knots, and the roaring seas, and all that; smite my timbers, but it was enough to melt the heart of a grampus. Poor Jack, he taught me the only song I ever knew, it's a main good one though — —
sp.l: In the time of the Rump
With his broom swept the chops of the Channel;

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.stage: ( putting her hand on his mouth. )
sp.p: Oh, uncle, uncle, don't sing that horrible rough song.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Rough? that's the beauty of it. It rouses one up, pipes all hands to quarters like a boatswain's call. Go in, Mary, but go in at the other door; don't go near the bar; go up to your own room, my dear, and your music-master will come to you presently, never fear.

div.stage: Exit Mary , U. E. L.

sp.speaker: Voice within
sp.p: Hollo — house! waiter! Captain Copp! another bottle, my hearty fellow.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
There they go again! I can't stand it any longer. I am an old cruiser, and can't hear an engagement without longing to be in the midst of it. Avast, though
( stopping short ,)
these lads are spending too much money. Have a care, friend Copp, don't sink the sailor in the publican; don't let a free-hearted tar ruin himself in thy house — no, no, faith. If they want more wine they shall have it; but they shall drink as messmates, not as guests. So have at you, boys; it's my turn to treat now. "In the time of the rump."

div.head: Scene II.
div.stage: — A room in Copp's house. Stairs 2 E. R. A large window in flat, L. with shutters closed.
Enter Mary , L.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: How provoking this absence of Mr. Georgini! — It would be serving him right to let my uncle discharge him: but then I should like just to learn that song he is teaching me — hark! — How my heart beats! Hark! I'll wager it's Georgini — I have a gift of knowing people before I see them — my heart whispers me —

div.stage: Enter Edward as Georgini , L.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: So, sir, you are come at last, are you! I had supposed you did not intend to come any more, and was about to look out for another teacher.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Pardon me for my absence — you have no idea what I have suffered.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Suffered! Have you been ill then?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Very ill —

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Indeed! and what was your complaint?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: The not seeing you.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Mighty fine, sir; it's a complaint that you might have cured in a moment. I have been angry, sir — very angry at your neglect — don't smile, sir — I won't be laughed at —

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Laugh at you! Can you suspect me of such a thing? — I do but smile from the pleasure of seeing you again — nothing but circumstances that I could not controul caused my absence.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Well, it's very provoking to be interrupted in one's lessons just in the middle of a new song — I'll warrant you've been teaching it all over town.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Indeed I teach it to no one but yourself — for no one else can do it such justice.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Nay, now you are flattering — have you brought it with you?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Here it is — if you please, we will sing it at once.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes — but — but — don't look so steadily at me while I sing — it puts me out; and then — and then — I don't know what I'm singing.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: What! — have you fear of me then?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh! yes; I fear that I may not please you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: A miable innocence! for the world I would not betray thee.

div.stage: SONG INTRODUCED.
Mrs. Knight.
Enter Copp , a little gay, singing, L.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Aha! master crotchet and quaver, so you've come at last, have you? What the deuce did you stay away for, and let my little girl get out of tune?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Oh! I have explained all, sir, and made my peace.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ah, she's a forgiving little baggage, and amazing fond of music — why she's always on the look out for you an hour before the time.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Never mind, uncle. Are your strange companions here still?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Here still? ay, and likely to stay here — ha! ha! ha! — no getting rid of them — they're a couple of devils, of right down merry devils, ha! ha! They've flustered me a little, i' faith.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: You seem to have a great deal of company in the house, sir; I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
You shall take no such thing — you shall take tea with us, my little semibreve, and we'll have a lesson of music too. Oddsfish! you shall give me a lesson — I am confoundedly out of practice, and can't turn my old song for the life of me —
( begins. )
"In the time of the Rump" —

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Never mind the song now, uncle, we must have tea first, and Mr. Georgini will help me make it.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Ay, faith, and we'll take a bowl of punch and a flask of old Madeira to make a set out —
(X R.)
my two messmates in the other room are to be of the party.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: What! those wild sailors who have been keeping the house in an uproar?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: To be sure — they're good lads, though they have a little of the devil in them. They asked to clink the cup with me, and you know I can't well refuse, by trade, to clink the cup with any one. In troth they had put me in such rare good humor — ha! ha! ha! — that I could not refuse them for the life of me.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: But they are such a couple of harebrains —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Oh! don't be afraid — they are rough, but good natured — sailor-like: besides, am not I always within hail? One of them, I see, is heaving in sight already. Come with me, my girl, and help to prepare the punch and get the tea — you my king of crotchets, will stay and receive our guests — make yourself at home —
( sings as he goes. )
"In the time of the Rump" —

div.stage: Exeunt Copp and Mary up stairs.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
Here's a transformation! from a court page behold me master of ceremonies at a Wapping tavern.
( starts. )
Good heaven! whom have we here? The Earl of Rochester in that rude garb!

div.stage: Enter Rochester , ( laughing. ) L.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! The shouts of those jolly fellows began to turn my brain — his majesty is in fine humor to get into a scrape; and if he does, to make his difficulties more perplexing, I have secured his purse, so that he cannot bribe his way out of them — Hey! Edward!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: My lord Rochester —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Silence, you rogue! I am no lord here, no Rochester. I am a seaman — my name Tom Taffrel. The king, my messmate, is Jack Mizen.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
The king with you! —
( aside )
I see it all — he's after Mary — ah! I am lost.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, friend Georgini; none but the most innocent motives have brought us here —

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
Innocent motives bring you and the king, at
night to a tavern in Wapping, where there is a beautiful girl? Ah! my lord, my lord —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Nay, to convince you that you have nothing to fear, I permit you to remain with us —
( aside. )
He may assist my scheme —
( aloud. )
You must play off your character of music-master upon the king.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Impossible! His majesty will recognize my features.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Psha! you have not been page a month; he probably has not seen your face three times. But take care how you act; the least indiscretion on your part —

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Ah! my lord, I am too much interested in keeping the secret.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: That is not all. In whatever situation the king may find himself, whatever chagrin he may suffer, I forbid you to assist him in the slightest manner. You are to see in him only the sailor, Jack Mizen.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Should his majesty chance to incur any danger, my lord, I can never be passive. In such case, I have but one course.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: There can be no danger — I shall myself watch over his safety.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: That decides me — I think I apprehend the object, and will obey your lordship.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: The king approaches — Silence! let each resume his part.

div.stage: Enter Charles , L.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Yo ho! well, messmate, shall we soon see this marvellous beauty?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: So — this is his majesty's innocent motive.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Peace, friend Jack, here's one of her admirers — her music-master —

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Ah! you teach the young lady music, do you?
(X c)
( looking earnestly at him. )
Zounds! how like he is to the page you gave me lately.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Ah! my face strikes him.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Hum — I can't say I see much-resemblance.
He is taller than Edward, and older, and the expression of his countenance is not the same.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: No, no, not altogether, but there is a something —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Why, to tell the truth, the page had a wild fellow for a father — and, your majesty knows, likenesses are stamped at random about the world sometimes.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I understand — duplicate impressions — like enough.

div.stage: Enter Mary and Servant, with Tea, down stairs

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Set the table in this room.

div.stage: ( the Servant and Mary puts tea things in order. )

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: By heaven she's a divinity!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: What does he say?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: That your divinity is a devilish fine girl.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Amuse this confounded singing-master. I wish to have a duo with his mistress. He'll only mar music.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.stage: ( to Edward, with an air of great business )
sp.p:
My good Mr. Georgini, I have something particular to say to you —
( drawing him to a corner. )
His majesty
(suppressing a laugh)
fancies that you are uncomfortable, and requests me to amuse you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
Yes, that he may have Mary all to himself
( drawing near her. )

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Come, don't be childish. What, you pretend to follow my lessons, and want complaisance?

div.stage: ( Charles has been making advances to Mary, who appears at first a little shy. )

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Do let me assist you, my pretty lass.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Don't trouble yourself sir; Mr. Georgini is to help me make tea.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I am here, madam — what can I do to help you?

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.stage: ( puts the kettle as if accidentally against his hand. ) —
sp.p: Take care, young man, you may scald your fingers.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.stage: ( drawing Edward back, and speaking low. )
sp.p: Why, what a plague, boy, are you doing?

div.stage: ( Charles continues to assist Mary, mingling little gallantries, and blundering in attempts to assist.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I shall go mad!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
Oh dear, sir, you're so kind, you quite put me out —
( laughing )
— hey! — you have taken my hand instead of the teapot. I will not say you're awkward, sir, but really you have the oddest manner of assisting — nay — let go my hand, I beg.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: By heaven, it is a beautiful one!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
Nay, nay — pray, sir —
( withdrawing her hand with smiling confusion. )
—
( apart. )
Upon my word, I don't see any thing so very rude in these people.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.stage: ( endeavouring to get away from Rochester. )
sp.p: Let me go, I entreat you; I can stand this no longer.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.stage: ( holding him, and suppressing a laugh. )
sp.p: Psha! man, if you think to marry, or rise in the world, you must learn to be deaf and blind upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.stage: ( in rather an under tone to Mary. )
sp.p: And how is it possible so pretty a lass should not be married?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Married! bless me! I never thought of such a thing.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: No? never? and yet surrounded by lovers.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Lovers! I hav'n't one, sir.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Indeed! and what is that young man fidgetting yonder?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: He? — he is my singing-master, sir.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: And he sings to some purpose, I'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Delightfully.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: And gives you a love-song now and then?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh often, often.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I thought so — he has it in his countenance.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: You must let me go — you see I am wanted.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Upon my word they are getting on amazingly well without you.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: And so you are fond of music, my pretty lass?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, I love it of all things.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: A pretty hand to beat time with

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Sir —

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: And as pretty a little mouth to warble a love song. I warrant there comes none but sweet notes from these lips

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Sir, give over — let me go sir. — Mr. Georgini — help, help!

div.stage: ( Edward bursts from Rochester, who is laughing. At this moment ,
Enter Copp , from stairs, with punch.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Avast there, messmate! what the devil, yard arm and yard arm with my niece!

div.stage: ( Charles desists, a little confused — Edward approaches Mary. )

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I am glad you are come, uncle — this rude stranger — —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.stage: ( taking her arm under his, and puts her over to R.)
sp.p: Thunder and lightning — what! insult Captain Copp's niece in his own house! Fire and furies!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.stage: ( pretending to be a little gay. )
sp.p: I insult your niece, messmate? Since when has an honest tar's kissing a pretty girl been considered an insult? As to the young woman, if she takes offence at a piece of sailor civilty, why I ask pardon, that's all.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oh, as to a piece of civility, d'ye see, that alters the case; but, guns and blunderbusses! if any one should dare — — -

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Come, come, uncle Copp, what a plague! you were a youngster once, and a frolicksome one, I'll warrant. I see it in your eye — what — didst ever think it a crime to kiss a pretty girl in a civil way.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
No, no, in a civil way, no certainly; I can make allowance when a lad and a lass, and a bottle come pretty near each other — odds fish — you say right, at your age I was a rattler myself. Come, Mary,
( Mary goes up to seat ,)
no harm done — Come, lads, take your seats —
( They seat themselves. Edward attempts to place himself by Mary — Charles interferes and takes the place; Edward then attempts to place himself at Mary's left hand, Rochester pops himself into the chair. )
Come, my girl, pour out the tea — I'll fill out the punch, and we'll have a time of it, i'faith — Come, I'll give you a jolly song to begin with —
sp.l: In the time of the Rump,

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: That odious song! — come uncle, never mind the song, take a cup of tea —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: What, drown my song and myself in warm water? ha! ha! no faith — not while there's a drop in the punch bowl.

div.stage: ( Mary helps Edward and Rochester, omitting Charles. )

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Am I then excluded?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I thought punch would be more to your liking, sir.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Then punch be it — Come, clink with me, neighbour Copp — clink with me, my boy.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oh! I'm not proud, I'll clink with any body — that's to say, mind ye, when the liquor is good, and there's a good fellow in the case.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Well, here goes — To the health of Mary, the fair maid of Wapping.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: With all my heart, here's to her health; the darling child — Oh; messmate, there you touch a soft corner of my heart — did you but know how I love this little girl. Psha! I'm a foolish old fellow, and when I have got punch, and sensibility, and all that on board — Come, let's talk of something else.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: My dear uncle — —

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I don't wonder at your loving her, I can't help feeling a kind of admiration for her myself —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Softly, shipmate, no grappling — admire at a distance as much as you please, but hands off. Come, my lads, a merry song — I love to sing when I drink.
sp.l: In the time of the Rump,

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Not that song, my dear uncle — I entreat —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ah, I recollect — ha! ha! my poor song; ha! ha! — well, well, since you don't like me to sing, sing it for me yourself, Mary.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Ay, a song from the charming Mary,
( significantly. )
I dare say your master has some pretty love song for you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Oh yes — I have brought one of the latest in vogue — one by the most fashionable poet of the day, the Earl of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Rochester? fire and fury — roast Rochester! a rascally rogue! the devil take Rochester, and his song too.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Bravo! Captain Copp — another broadside, old boy —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Why, what the deuce, neighbour — has your powder magazine taken fire? Why, what has Rochester done to you, to occasion such a terrible explosion?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: What's that to you? What have you to do with my family secrets? Rochester! His very name makes my blood boil —

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: My dear uncle, be calm. You promised never to speak on this subject.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Why, what connection can there be between you and Rochester?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
No matter, he has been put to the proof, that's enough.
( To Mary. )
Don't be uneasy — I'll say no more about it, my girl. You know me — when I say mum, that's enough — honour bright.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
This affair seems serious —
( rises. )
I must have an explanation.
( With an air of authority. )
It is my pleasure —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Your pleasure, quotha — and who the devil are you? You're a pleasant blade.
( Sturdily. )
But it's not my pleasure, messmate, look ye.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I mean to say, that I feel a deep interest in your welfare.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Thank ye, thank'e, — but I'm not used to such warm friends on such short acquaintance.
( Apart. )
I wonder is it myself, or my niece, this chap has fallen in love with at first sight?

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I am curious to know what charge they have against you.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: And so am I, and I'll make this old buccaneer speak plain, before we leave him.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: You have misunderstood me, friend Copp. I am no defender of Rochester. I know him to be a sad fellow.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: As destitute of feeling as a stock fish.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: He is a great genius, however.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: He is an evil genius, I know.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: He has a very clear head —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: But a very black heart.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: This Rochester is a sad light-headed fellow, that's notorious; but will you have the goodness, my blunt Captain Copp, to mention one heartless act of his?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ay, that I will. Is it not a burning shame —

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: My dear uncle, you forget your promise.

div.stage: ( on R.)

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Let me alone, girl, let me alone — you've nothing to fear; I have you under convoy.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Out with it, what is his crime?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Crime! Is it not a burning shame, I say, to disclaim his own niece — to keep from her every stiver of her little fortune, and leave her to pass her days in a tavern, when she has a right to inhabit a palace?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: What, and is this young woman the niece? How can that be?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Simply enough. Her father. Philip Copland, married a sister of Lord Rochester.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Philip Copland is indeed the name.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: This is most singular. And this Philip Copland was your brother?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ay, but worth a dozen of me — a steady man, an able officer, an ornament of the regular navy. I was always a wild dog, and never took to learning — ran away from school — shipped myself on board a privateer. In time I became captain, and returned from my last cruise just in time to receive poor Philip's last breath — his sand was almost run out. 'Brother,' said he, 'I feel that my cruising is over; but there's my little girl. Take care of her for my sake, and never bother the Rochesters again.' — 'Brother,' said I, 'it's a bargain; tip us your fist on it, and die in peace, like a good christian.' He grasped my hand, and gave it a gentle squeeze. I would have shook his, but it grew cold, and poor Philip was no more!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.stage: ( laying her hand on his shoulder. )
sp.p: My dear uncle —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
But the girl was left, the girl was left
( embracing her )
; and —
( taking her arm under his )
and I'll keep my word to my poor brother, and take care of her , as long as I have breath in my body.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Well, brother Tom, what do you think of all this?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: It touches me to the soul.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: And so you took home the child?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh! yes: and my uncle's bounty and kindness have taken care of his poor girl ever since.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oh! you should have seen what a little thing it was, — a little chubby-faced thing of four years old, no higher than a handspike. Now she's a grown girl.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: And you have given her a good education, it appears?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
And why not? What, tho' I'm a dunce,
that's no reason that Mary Copland should be a fool. Her father was a man of parts.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: And you have given up your voyages for her?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: To be sure. Could I have a child running after me about deck? I sold my ship, and bought this tavern, where I receive none but good fellows, who drink, and smoke, and talk to me of voyages and battles all day long.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: But ambition might have induced you —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ambition! You don't know me: my only ambition is to marry my niece to some honest citizen, and give her a dower of one thousand pounds, with as much more when old Captain Copp takes his long map.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Generous fellow!
( Aloud. )
Let me advise you to apply to the Earl of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Oh! yes, he will provide an honourable match for your niece.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Much obliged, Mr Georgini, but nobody asked your advice.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Apply to him! — no — no — I'll have nothing to do with the Rochesters.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: But why not apply to the king himself?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oddsfish! They say he is not much better, he's a wild devil — a great friend of Rochester — and birds of a feather, you know —

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Now comes my turn.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: True enough, Captain Copp, they say he is a rover — rambles about at night — frolics in taverns.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Well, let him cruise, so he does not cruise into my waters. He's a desperate rogue among the petticoats, they say — well, I like a merry heart, wherever it beats. — Charley has some good points — Oh! dam'me, I like Charley — and if I could but give him a piece of my mind —

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: What would it be, friend Copp?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
To keep more in port, anchor himself at home, and turn that fellow, Rochester, adrift — there might then be some hopes of him. — But, come, 'tis
getting late — now, friends, it's time to turn out, and turn in — these are late hours for the Grand Admiral, come, a parting cup. —
( To Mary. )
See that the fires are out, my girl, and all hands ready for bed.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I will, but no more drinking, uncle.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Well, well — no more — only one parting cup.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Only one — recollect, you have promised — no more.

div.stage: ( Charles sits at the table, with his back to L.)

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Only this last drop. — Come, my lads, this farewell cup, and then you must push your boats.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Now to execute my plan,
( making signs that the king will pay. )
Hist, Captain Copp!

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.stage: ( Goes up to Chas. at table )
sp.p: Ay, ay, all right.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Follow me quietly — I've some thing to say to you.
( Apart, and chuckling as he goes out. )
Now brother Jack, I think you'll soon find yourself among the breakers!

div.stage: Exit L. followed by Edward.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Now, messmate, let's square accounts, —
( handling a paper )
here's a note of your expenses — you see I charge nothing for the last two bottles — nor for the tea-table — that's my treat.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Um! wine — punch — wine — punch — total five pounds ten — a mere trifle.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Do you call that a trifle? — Gad, messmate, you must have made good prizes in your last cruise, or you've high wages, mayhap.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Ay, ay, I'm pretty well paid — Here Tom Taffrel, pay Copp's bill, and let's be off. —
( looking round )
Hey — where is he?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oh! he went off in a great hurry — he said he had to be aboard ship, but that you would pay the bill.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
With all my heart. —
( Apart )
It's odd that he should leave me alone — my raillery has galled him. — Poor Rochester,
( laughing )
how ill some people take a joke! —
( feeling his pockets )
Five pounds ten, you say.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Just so — five pounds ten.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Well! this is the oddest thing — I am certain I had my purse.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: My neighbour seems rather in a quandary.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Some one has picked my pocket.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Avast there, friend — none but honest people frequent the Grand Admiral. —
( Apart )
I begin to suspect this spark, who spends so freely, is without a stiver in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: All I know, is, that one of those honest people must have taken my purse.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Come, come, messmate — I am too old a cruiser to be taken in by so shallow a manæuvre — I understand all this — your companion makes sail — you pretend to have been robbed — it's all a cursed privateerig trick — clear as day.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Friend Copp — if you will wait till to-morrow, I'll pay you double the sum.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Double the sum!! — thunder and lightning! what do you take me for? — Look ye, neighbour, to an honest tar in distress, my house and purse are open — to a jolly tar who wants a caper, and has no coin at hand, drink to-day and pay to-morrow is the word — but to a sharking land lubber, that hoists the colours of a gallant cruiser, to play off the tricks of a pirate, old Copp will show him his match any day.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: A land lubber?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ay, a land lubber. — D'ye think I can't see through you, and your shallow sailor phrases. — Who the devil are you? — none of the captains know you, what ship do you belong to?

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
What ship? why to — to —
( apart )
what the deuce shall I say?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: A pretty sailor truly — not know the name of his ship — a downright swindler — a barefaced impudent swindler — comes into my house, kicks up a bobbery, puts every thing in an uproar — treats all the guests — touzles my niece — and then wants to make off without paying.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
How shall I get out of this cursed scrape? — Oh, happy thought! my watch —
( aloud )
hearkee, Captain Copp — if I haven't money, may be this will do as well — what say you to my watch as pledge?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Let me see it, um, large diamonds —

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Well — that's worth your five pounds ten — hey?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Um — I don't know that: — if the diamonds are false , it is not worth so much — if real , none but a great lord could own it —
( turning quick to him )
how did you come by this watch?

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: It's my own.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Your own! A common sailor own a watch set with large diamonds! I'll tell you what, my hearty, it's my opinion as how you stole this watch.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Stole it? Give back my watch, fellow, or I'll —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Softly, my lad, keep cool, or I'll have you laid by the heels in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: What a bull-dog! Well, sir, what do you intend to do?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Lock you up here for the present, and have you lodged in limbo immediately.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Will you listen to reason?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Yes, through the key-hole!
( from the door )
You shall have news of me presently, my fine fellow.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Was ever monarch in such a predicament! — a prisoner in a tavern — to be presently dragged through the streets as a culprit — and to-morrow sung in lampoons, and stuck up in caricatures all through the city — what is to be done? This Copp seems a man of probity, suppose I avow myself to him? Um! will he credit me, and will he keep the matter secret? This sturdy veteran may be an old cruiser under the Commonwealth: if so, what have I not to apprehend? Alone, unarmed, at midnight
( shaking his head )
— Charles, Charles! wilt thou never learn wisdom? —
( a noise of unlocking the door )
Hark! some one comes.

div.stage: Enter Edward and Mary , at door.
Several Servants quaintly dressed, and armed, appear at the door.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Place yourselves outside, and guard the passages.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: They are placing sentinels.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: The earl has given me my lesson: no flinching.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I am afraid to go near him. I wish my uncle had not set us this task. —

div.stage: ( Mary is armed with an old cutlas, Edward with a long rusty pistol or carbine. )

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Be not afraid, I am here to defend you.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: What! my pretty Mary in arms?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Ah, don't come near me! What a ferocious ruffian it is.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Was that delicate hand made to grasp so rude a weapon?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Don't let him touch your hand or you are lost.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: He does not look so very ferocious neither. Fie, sir, fie! what, steal the jewels of the crown?

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Is it then known already?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, all is known. My uncle took the watch to our neighbour, the jeweller, who knew it instantly. It belongs to his royal majesty himself.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
You hear, he confesses. —
( Aloud )
Well, Captain Copp will be here presently with the magistrate. Here will be a fine piece of work. All Wapping is already in an uproar.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: My friends, it is of the highest importance that I should escape before they come.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I have not a doubt of it. Oh, you culprit!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: And would Mary, the pretty Mary, see me dragged to prison? I won't believe it. That sweet face bespeaks a gentle heart.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Poor creature! I can't but pity him.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
I never saw a pretty woman yet, that would not help a poor fellow in distress —
( apart )
she yields. But I need other bribes for my gentleman — I have it — my ring.
( Aloud )
Assist me to escape, and take this ring as a pledge of what I will do. It is of great value.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: What a beautiful diamond ring! how it sparkles! Don't touch it, Georgini, it's a stolen ring.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: And for that very reason I take it. We can return both together to the right owner.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: He certainly has something genteel in his air. This unfortunate man may perhaps belong to decent people.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I do indeed; my family is considered very respectable. Ah, bless that sweet face! I knew a hard heart could not belong to it.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Egad, I must get him off, or he'll win his pretty jailer, culprit as she thinks him.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: How penitent he seems, and his countenance is rather amiable, too! What will they do with him?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Lock him up in a dungeon — put him in irons — keep him on bread and water.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Shocking! my heart feels for him — so sweet spoken a man! How long will they confine him?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Can't say — may be, two or three days — may be, two or three weeks. Then, they'll hang him.

div.stage: ( Charles comes from stair-case, goes to the window, and opens shutters )

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Heavens! will they touch his life?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Oh yes, they'll certainly hang him. I shall attend the execution — I never saw a man hanged.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh horrible! and so good looking a man!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Yes, he'll make a very pretty figure.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I would not have his death upon my mind for the whole world.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.stage: ( who has been traversing the apartment uneasily, and eying them occasionally. )
sp.p:
Will this consultation
never end! I dread the arrival of the officers.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Let us assist him to escape!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Thanks, my generous girl: there's nothing like a petticoat in time of trouble.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: How shall we get him off? the door is guarded.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Ay, but the window.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: No, not the window, you may hurt yourself.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: You are very considerate, my friend.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh! it is not very high, and opens into a lane that leads to the river.

sp.speaker: Chas.
Mary.
sp.p: It is, perhaps, very wrong in me to let you escape; but I beg you to listen to a word of advice.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Oh, yes, I hear you.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: It is on condition that you change your course of life.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I'll change it, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: And not drink, nor rove about this way at night.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: And steal no more, for it will bring you to a shameful end.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.stage: ( getting out of the window assisted by Mary. )
sp.p: An excellent sermon! But I must steal — one kiss to impress it on my memory!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Did he steal a kiss, Mary?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, yes, he did indeed.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Stop thief! stop thief!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Tell uncle Copp to put it in the bill!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
I hear them coming
( looks out of the window. )
He's safe down — he's off
( apart )
— now I'm easy.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: But what shall we say to my uncle?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
I'll manage that; only say as I say, and fear
nothing. Stop thief! stop thief!
( To Mary )
Cry out as I do!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Stop the thief! stop the thief! — I can't.

div.stage: Enter Copp , L. with a double-barrelled gun, followed by two servants.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Hollo! what the devil's to pay here?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: The culprit has jumped out of the window.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, yes, out of the window.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! why didn't you stop him?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I was too far off. The young lady attempted, but he kissed her, and leaped out like a greyhound.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Fire and furies! kissed her?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Yes, uncle, but he didn't hurt me.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: And he said you might put it in the bill.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.stage: ( Bustle — Copp fires off his gun twice out of the window after Charles )
sp.p:
Guns and blunderbusses! this is running up an account with a vengeance
( looking out of the window. )
I see something in the offing; we may overhaul him yet. Come along, all hands to the chase! Get to your room, Mary, there's no knowing what might happen if this pirate should fall foul of you again. Come along — away with you all — divide at the street door — scour the three passages — I'll show him what it is to come in the way of an old cruiser!

div.stage: Exeunt — Mary R., the rest c.
END OF THE SECOND ACT.

div.head: Scene
div.stage: — The Royal Palace. Arm-chair, and table, with pen, ink, and paper upon it.
Enter Edward , in his habit, as a Page, E.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
I've had a hard scramble of it, to get here, and dress in time. The king must arrive presently, thought my light heels have given me a good start of him. Ha! ha! ha! I cannot help laughing
(sits)
tho' I do it with fear and trembling, to think of the confounded prank that mad wag, Rochester, has played off upon majesty.
( noise R. U. E.)
Hark! a noise in the king's private staircase — Softly, then, softly
( seats himself in an arm-chair at the door of the king's chamber, and pretends to sleep. )
L.

div.stage: Enter Charles , his dress in disorder from Sd E. R.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Confound the city! what a journey it is!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Especially to foot passengers.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
I began to think I should never find the palace.
( Sitting down )
Phew! I shall not forget this night in a hurry. Forced to escape like a thief, — to risk my neck from a window, — hunted about the streets by that old buccaneer and his crew! Egad! I fancy I can hear old Copp's voice, even now, like a huntsman giving the view-halloo, as I doubled about the mazes of Wapping.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: A royal hunt, truly!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: And, then, such perplexities in finding my way! jeered by the watchman, dogged by a couple of fellows, who seemed looking out for a convenient place to demand my purse. Faith, they would have looked as foolish as myself at the emptiness of my pockets. Well, thank fortune, I am safe at home at last, and seen by nobody but my confidential valet.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: And the most discreet of pages.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
So, the page already in waiting.
Deuce take him! he is exactly in the door-way of my chamber. So, so! Lady Clara coming! Oh, then, all's over.

div.stage: Enter Lady Clara , R. — goes to Edward.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: What! asleep at this hour, Edward?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, my lady — I am waiting his majesty's rising.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p:
You will come, and let the queen know when the king is visible.
( perceives Chas. )
Heavens! your majesty in this dress?

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Good morning, Lady Clara.
( aside. )
I wish I may die, if I know how to turn the matter off.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: I ask your majesty's pardon; but really, I cannot help laughing — So odd a dress.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: What! it amuses you, ha! ha! My regular morning dress, I assure you. I have taken a whim for gardening lately, and, every morning, by day-light, I am on the terrace, planting, transplanting, training. Oh! you should see how busy I am, particularly among the roses.

sp.speaker: Lony C.
sp.p: I have no doubt your majesty has an eye for every fresh one that blows — But, how quiet you have been in these pursuits!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: One does not want all the world to know of one's caprices.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Caprices! how can your majesty call such an innocent occupation by such a name. How happy the nation, whose sovereign has a taste so pure, so simple!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Well, well, a truce with your moral reflections — What has procured me the pleasure of seeing your ladyship so early?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: The Queen, sir, knowing how deeply you were immersed in affairs of state last night —

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Why, yes, in truth I had a busy night of it.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: She sent me to inquire how your majesty had slept.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Very restless — very restless — I tumbled and tossed about sadly.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Ah! why does not your majesty take more care of yourself? You devote yourself too much to yourpeople. This night-work will be too much for you.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Why, yes, if it were often as severe as last night.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Indeed, your majesty must give up these midnight labours to your ministers.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
To my miniisters, ha! ha! Egad! I should like to see old Clarendon and Ormond hob or nobbing with uncle Copp, struggling for kisses with Mary, and scouring the lanes of Wapping at full speed. —
( aloud. )
Well, my Lady Clara, have you any thing further to communicate?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Might I presume, I have a favour to request of your majesty. An author, in whose cause I take a warm interest, has offended a person high in power, and is threatened with a prosecution.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: The blockhead! let him write against me only, and they'll never trouble him.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: His pardon depends upon your majesty, would you but deign to sign it!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Lady Clara, you look amazingly well this morning — I can refuse you nothing —
( signs the paper. )
And now, to make my toilette. —
( aside. )
Safe at last! — she suspects nothing.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p:
He thinks he has deceived me. Oh, these men! these men! how they will impose upon us, easy, simple, knowing women!
( to Edw. )
A person from the city, with a young girl, desires to speak to his majesty, you will permit them to await him here. I will myself conduct them.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
This should be Captain Copp. In his blunt honesty, he determined to bring the watch himself to the king — But why his neice? No doubt, to let her have a sight of the Palace. Here they come, sure enough — now for another puzzle about my physiognomy.
( retires up a little. )

div.stage: Enter Copp and Mary from the back door, flat.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oddsfish! I never knew such a piece of work to get into a house before. If that good-looking gentlewoman had not seen us from the window, and taken our part, hand me, if I don't think they would have turn'd us adrift.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: So — I suspect Lady Clara is in the plot.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: What beautiful rooms!

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Gingerbread finery! I would not change the bar-room of the Grand Admiral for the best of them. But, what a bother to give a watch back to the right owner! Why, there's no finding the king in his own house. — Now, for my part, I always stand on the threshold, and if any one comes, there's my hand. — Tip us your bone, says I, and make yourselves welcome. — That's what I call acting like a king of good fellows.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, uncle, I have always heard say, that the king is very kind and affable; and, I dare say, when you hand him back his watch, he will behave with generosity.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Generosity! Why, dost thou think, girl, I'd take a reward? No, no! — They say Charley's not overstocked with the shiners — I want none of them. To be sure, he may do the civil thing — he may ask us to stay, and take pot-luck, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Pot-luck, uncle!

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ay, in a friendly way, d'ye see? And I don't care if I did, if it were only to see how royalty messed. But, where the deuce is the king to be found? Oh! yonder is a fine gimcrack young gentleman, who, perhaps, can tell us — I'll hail him. Yo-ho! messmate!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: What a beautiful place this is! But, without content, grandeur is not to be envied. The humble, and the good, may be as happy in a cottage as a palace.

div.stage: Enter Copp , pulling in Edward , who tries to hide his face.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Come along, young man — don't be so bashful — you needn't mind us.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p:
Let me put on a steady face,
( aloud )
— You come to speak to his majesty?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir, we come —
( (apart. )
Dear uncle, those features — how my heart beats!

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Why what ails thee, my girl?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Is any thing the matter with the young lady? let me assist her.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Thank'ee, thank'ee,
( putting up his elbow )
young gentleman — But, by your leave, if you please.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Did you ever see such a resemblance, uncle?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oddsfish! he is like indeed! — But it can't be him.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I like Mr. Georgini's face better — it is more animated.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Don't talk to me of that Georgini. Didst not tell me, he took a ring of that land-pirate? — and, then to disappear so suddenly —

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: How can you suspect him, uncle? The most honourable — the most upright — I dare say he only took it, to keep for the right owner.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Dear, confiding Mary!

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: That ring should not have remain'd in his hands a single moment. — It may bring a suspicion on my house, on my character — Fire and fury, if I catch him!

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: No swearing in the King's palace.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: That's true; I should not swear. But, that old Captain Copp, whom every body knows to be honest, should have such tricks play'd in his house, thunder and lightning!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: My dear uncle!

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Well, well, true — no swearing. But what keeps the king so long?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: I think I hear him. Step into that apartment — a lady will introduce you.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ah! the same that I saw at the window; — very well. But, I say, Mister, don't keep me waiting. Just hint to the king, that I've no time to lose. Tell him, there's a launch at Wapping to-day — busy times at the Grand Admiral.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Let us retire, uncle. I dare say we shall be sent for in good time.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Very well, very well. But, do think of the Grand Admiral — all aback for want of me. If the king loses his watch again, the devil take me — — Oh! I forgot — I mustn't swear in the king's palace.

div.stage: Exeunt Copp and Mary, R.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: This will be a whimsical court presentation truly! His majesty's perplexities are not yet over.

div.stage: Enter Charles in his riding dress. L.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Has Rochester appeared?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Not yet, Sire.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: What could be his motive for the cruel trick he played me?

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Your majesty asked for Lord Rochester; here he comes with Lady Clara.

div.stage: Enter Rochester and Lady Clara , R.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: May I venture to ask, if your majesty has passed a comfortable night?

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Indifferent, my lord —
( low, to him )
— Traitor!

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: I understood his lordship had assisted your majesty in your labours.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Not throughout, my lady. An accident obliged me to leave his majesty in rather a moment of perplexity.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Yes, his lordship left the whole weight of — business — upon my shoulders.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: I doubt not your majesty got through with your usual address.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Perfidious varlet!
( aloud. )
My lord, you will please to present yourself in my study at
two o'clock. I have something particular to say to you.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Deign to dispense with my attendance, sire. I quit London in a few moments for my estate, as I mentioned yesterday. I am a great offender — It is time to exile myself from court, and turn hermit.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I approve the project; but will take the liberty of choosing your hermitage myself.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: The king is furious against me.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Courage, my lord — all will end well.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: What the devil is the meaning of all this? Am I to be kept here all day?

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: What uproar is that?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Oh! two persons, whom I met this morning, seeking to speak with his majesty, on some personal concern. As I know him to be so accessible to the people, I undertook to present them.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Just now it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: I am very sorry, especially on the young girl's account.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: A young girl, did you say?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Beautiful as an angel!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
O! since you take such interest in her, lady Clara —
( to Edward. )
— Show them in.

div.stage: ( retires up. )
Enter Copp and Mary , R.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Come in — his majesty consents to hear you.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: I'm taken all aback — my courage begins to fail me.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.stage: ( Mary keeps her eyes modestly cast down. )
sp.p: What have you to fear, my dear uncle? —

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Fear! it isn't fear, look ye. But, somehow, I never fell in with a king before in all my cruisings.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Copp and his neice!
( advances. )
here's a pretty rencontre
( summoning up dignity. )

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Well, I suppose I must begin — Oddsfish! I had it all settled in my head, and now, the deuce a word can I muster up.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Come, uncle, courage! I never saw you so cast down before.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I hope he will not recognize me.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Is not my niece a pretty lass?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: She is, indeed, my lord; you may be proud of her.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Well, then, what I have to say is this.
( low. )
Hey, Mary, what is it I had to say?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Relate simply what passed.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Right, my girl, right. But, oddsfish, I feel so queer, I'll be hanged if I can look him in the face.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.stage: ( keeps her eyes modestly cast down. )
sp.p: It would not be respectful to stare at his majesty.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: What is your name, my good friend?

div.stage: ( to Copp. )

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.stage: ( while talking he looks down and fumbles with his cap. )
sp.p: Copp, at your service; that is to say, Coppland, or Captain Copp, as they call me. And here's Mary, my niece, who, though I say it, is one of the best girls —

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: But, that's not to the point, uncle.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Eh! true, very true, always keep to the point, like a good helmsman. First and foremost, then, you must know, my lord — when I say my lord, I mean your majesty.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Egad, he's as much puzzled as I was, to give an account of myself.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
In finis — you must know primo, that I command, that is to say, I keep the Grand Admiral, as honest a tavern as your majesty would wish to set your foot in — none but good company ever frequent it, excepting when a rogue or so drops in, in disguise — last night, for instance, a couple of gallows knaves, saving your majesty's presence — Ah! if I could only lay eyes on them again — I should know 'em, wherever I saw 'em — one in particular had a confounded hanging look — a man about the height of —
( eyeing Rochester, stops short. )
Mary! Mary! if there isn't one of the very rogues!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
My dear uncle, hush, for heaven's sake! —
( apart. )
That wine is still in his head.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Rochester's face seems to puzzle him.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
I'll say no more; for the more I look —
( low to Mary )
hang me, if it isn't himself.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
Hush, I intreat you — I will speak for you —
( takes his place, her eyes still modestly cast down. )
My uncle has thought it his duty to inform your majesty, that two strangers came to his house last night, and after calling for a great deal of wine, were unable to pay, and went off, leaving a valuable watch in pledge, which has proved to belong to your majesty.

div.stage: ( Rochester and Lady Clara in bye play express great delight at the manner of Mary. )

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oh! bless her! she talks like a book.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Does not my niece tell her story with clearness and simplicity?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Charmingly — she has quite won my heart.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: My uncle being an honest man, has brought the watch to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Yes, by St. George, and here it is. The sharpers, to be sure, have run off with five pounds ten of my money, but that's neither here nor there — I don't say that, because I expect you to pay it, you know. In short, without more palaver,
( crossing, and giving it to Charles ,)
here's the watch —
( glancing at the king, stops short, and gives a long whistle ,)
whew!
( treads softly back )
—
( low to Mary. )
My shoes! if it ben't the other rogue!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: What ails you, uncle? surely, you are losing your senses to speak thus of his majesty?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Majesty, or no majesty, I'll put my hand in the fire on't he's the other.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: The watch is certainly mine.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Your majesty's?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Your majesty's watch!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Even so; and I might have lost it, but for this man's honesty. I shall be more on my guard in future.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: The voices and the faces are astonishingly like. But it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
I have it — I see how it is. —
( low to Mary. )
We've made a pretty kettle of fish of it. The king, you know, is said to cruise under false colours.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Mercy on me! what will become of us?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Let me alone — I see it's all a masquerade frolic —
( aloud. )
Your majesty will not be angry with my little fool of a niece. The two strangers might be very worthy people — many a man has a gallows look, and is an honest fellow for all that. The truth is, they were a brace of merry wags. Besides, if I had known for certain, I wouldn't for the world — ha! ha! — because, d'ye see — honour bright; mum!
( turning to Mary. )
Come, I think I've got you pretty well out of the scrape, hey?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: I am of your opinion, Captain Copp, they were two sad madcaps.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.stage: ( gives a sign to Edward, who brings forward a chair. )
sp.p: They merit harsher titles, Lady Clara. One of them has been already punished, the other shall be presently. Captain Copp, I am aware of all that passed at your house.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ah! your majesty knows, that he who cracks a joke must not complain if he should chance to pinch his fingers.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: True, Captain. But was there not question of one Rochester?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Zounds! that's his friend; this is bringing one to close quarters. Why, craving your majesty's pardon, I did let slip some hard truths about him.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: And do you know him of whom you spoke so bluntly?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Not I, thank heaven! But I only said, what
everybody says — and what everybody says, you know, must be true.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Spoken like an oracle — and did not you say, that this pretty lass was his niece?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Ay, as to that matter, I'll stick to that, proof in hand. Make a reverence, Mary, and no thanks to Rochester for the relationship.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I will take care that he shall make a suitable provision for his niece, or provide her an honourable husband.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
(X to Charles. )
I can assure your majesty, you only anticipated his intentions.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Avast there! — I don't give up my girl.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: But you will choose a match suited to her noble family.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: I'll choose for her an honest man; but no ranticumscout companion to suit that Earl of Rochester you talk of.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Poor Rochester; how many chance shots he gets. I feel more warmly in his favour, knowing how much of this censure is unmerited.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: To tell the truth between friends, and all in confidence, I had a match in my eye, a young music-master. Nay, don't blush, girl — I know there was a sneaking kindness in the case.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I oppose that match. That young man received a ring last night, but has not had the honesty, like Captain Copp, to seek the owner.

div.stage: ( Mary involuntarily springs forward to defend Edward against the charge, which Lady Clara and Rochester observe and smile at.)

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Oddsfish! that's true enough. — He has absconded with the ring.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I am a witness, that the ring was freely given to him, and I'll pledge my life that he will bring it back.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: He only waited a suitable moment to return it to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: How! Edward! — The resemblance is no longer a wonder.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: What, little crotchet and quaver! Aha! ha! ha! there's witchcraft in all this.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh heavens! Georgini a gentleman! But my heart knew it.

div.stage: ( Copp, Mary, and Edward go up the stage. )

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: It is in vain, Lady Clara, to attempt concealment. Behold the heroes of the adventure.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Pardon me, sire, I knew it all along — I was in the plot.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Her majesty, the queen, was at the head of it. If the earl be guilty, it is we who induced him, and should undergo the punishment.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I understand the whole. But the treachery of this earl I cannot forgive. To have made me pass two of the cruellest hours —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: I humbly acknowledge all my faults.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: To have exposed me, at night in the streets, where I was dogged by ruffians —

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: Ry two men in mantles who would have died ere a hair of your majesty was touched.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: Ah! who were those muffled men?

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
Your confidential valet was one. The other,
( bowing )
your devoted servant.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: No matter! I have been exposed, rendered ridiculous. You shall not obtain my pardon.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: It is already obtained. Your majesty, ever merciful, has signed it.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: What! he, too, is the author for whom you have interested yourself. Ha! ha! ha! fairly taken in at all points. Rochester, thou hast conquered. —

div.stage: (Rochester kneels. Charles and Lady Clara retire together, Copp and Mary come down.)

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Thunder and lightning! — this man Rochester! — come along, girl, come along!

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
One moment, Captain Copp. —
[ Copp stops, and looks fiercely at him.
It is true, I am Rochester — a sad fellow, no doubt,
since all the world says so — but there is one grievous sin which I will not take to my conscience, for it is against beauty. I am not the Rochester who disclaimed this lovely girl — he was my predecessor, and is dead.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p:
Dead! — gone to his long reckoning —
( pauses. )
May heaven deal kindlier with him, than he did with this orphan child!

div.stage: (Charles and Lady Clara advance.)

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: I have pardoned you, Rochester; but my eyes are opened to the follies which I have too frequently partaken. From this day I abjure them.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p:
I shall not attempt my liege, to gloss over, or to palliate my faults. But I place myself under the direction of this lovely guide.
(bowing to Lady C.)
I will mortify myself with matrimony, and hope to reform into a very rational and submissive husband.

sp.speaker: Lady. C.
sp.p: I have undertaken an arduous charge, my lord, and my happiness is the stake. Rochester must be reformed, or Clara lost.

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: There yet remains a party to be disposed of. What say you, Captain Copp? — What say you, my lord of Rochester? Must we not find a husband for our pretty niece?

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Fair and softly, your majesty — craving your majesty's pardon, I can't give up my right over my little girl. This lord is an uncle — I can't gainsay it; but he's a new-found uncle — for my part I have bred her, and fed her, and been her uncle all her life, haven't I, Mary?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, sir, you have been a father to me.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: My good little girl — my darling girl. Take thee away from thy own uncle? Pshaw! — Ha! ha! I shall grow silly and soft again! Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p: You are right, captain — you alone ought to dispose of her. But I hope to propose a match that shall please all parties. What think you of my page; the music-master, who brought back the ring? I shall present him with a commission in my own regiment.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Oh! so much goodness!

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: Your majesty has fathomed my own wishes.

sp.speaker: Roch.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
And —
(extending her hand)
— and mine.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.p: So, here we are, all safe in port, after last night's squall. Oddsfish! I feel so merry! — my girl's provided for — I have nothing more to care for — I'll keep open house at the Grand Admiral — I'll set all my liquor a-tap — I'll drown all Wapping in wine and strong beer — I'll have an illumination — I'll make a bonfire of the Grand Admiral — I'll sing "In the time of the Rump" —

div.stage: ( Mary runs down and stops him. )

sp.speaker: Chas.
sp.p:
Captain Copp, I recollect that I am your debtor — five pounds ten? — accept this watch as a mark of my esteem. The ring I reserve for the lovely Mary.
(putting it on her finger.)
And now,
(beckoning all the characters to the front with an air of mystery,)
let me particularly enjoin on all present, the most profound secrecy in regard to our whimsical adventures at Wapping.

sp.speaker: Copp.
sp.stage: ( clapping his finger to his lip )
sp.p: Honour bright! Mum! —

div.stage: (Curtain falls.)
